channel.title: Two ways of casting
channel.description:
So there are two ways to cast an object to another in Java.
You can use: [code] Object1 object1 = (Object1)object2; [/code]
Or you can do: [code] Object1 object1 = Object1.class.cast(object2); [/code] (i think that's correct)
I'm here to ask you which is better to use for casting objects that aren't primitive data types (int, double, float, etc).
For all of you who will tell me to google it, I did, I read, I just couldn't understand where this second form of casting would be required.

item.title: Two ways of casting
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Object howToProgram = new JButton("lol");
// damn, need to use my JButton!
Component myJButtonAux1 = (Component) howToProgram;
Container myJButtonAux2 = (Container) myJButtonAux1;
JComponent myJButtonAux3 = (JComponent) myJButtonAux2;
AbstractButton myJButtonAux4 = (AbstractButton) myJButtonAux3;
JButton myJButton = (JButton) myJButtonAux5;

myButton.setText("pro coder");

Read full topic

item.title: Two ways of casting
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:9, topic:546408”][quote author=object link=topic=665307.msg4447551#msg4447551 date=1409638707]
The question has already been answered, but, I prefer to use the latter, if possible. It’s more aesthetically pleasing to my eyes.
[/quote]

I hate how ugly casting looks.[/quote]
Exactly. That’s why I prefer the latter, as it looks more like any other method call. That, or doing int i = (int)(object);.

Read full topic

item.title: Two ways of casting
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“Eyeownyew, post:6, topic:546408”][quote author=Limits link=topic=665307.msg4447532#msg4447532 date=1409626215]

But there has to be a reason why they made two different ways of doing it when one is clearly faster to type.

One is used for reflection. Nobody uses reflection. There’s your answer

Okay thank you.
[/quote]
Of course glad I helped
Tbh I found most of that information by googling so I’d recommend doing that first in the future
unless your objective was to spur discussion which didn’t happen but I respect that if that was your aim[/quote]
I did google it but I couldn’t really understand why there are two ways to do it. The fact that you said “Nobody uses reflection.” answered my question. I wasn’t trying to spur discussion, only asking a question.

Read full topic

item.title: Two ways of casting
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Both are done at runtime, so it has no effect on performance.
I honestly don’t think it matters. You should refrain from doing casting whenever possible but if you must I don’t believe there’s a difference.

Read full topic

So there are two ways to cast an object to another in Java.

You can use:

(i think that’s correct)

I’m here to ask you which is better to use for casting objects that aren’t primitive data types (int, double, float, etc).
